questions.question: What does FPGA stand for in the context of chip design?
options: Field-Programmable Gate Array
Fast Processor Global Architecture
Fully Parallel General Algorithm
Flexible Peripheral Gate Automation
Floating Point Gate Array

questions.question: In the physical design stage of an Integrated Circuit, what is the primary objective of the "placement" step?
options: To convert the RTL description into a gate-level netlist.
To connect all power and ground rails to the standard cells.
To determine the optimal physical locations for all standard cells and macros on the chip die.
To verify that the timing constraints are met across all clock domains.
To generate the final GDSII file for manufacturing.

questions.question: In a classic five-stage RISC pipeline (Fetch, Decode, Execute, Memory, Write-back), what is the primary purpose of "data forwarding" (also known as bypassing)?
options: To predict the outcome of conditional branches to reduce control hazards.
To allow multiple instructions to execute simultaneously in different pipeline stages.
To resolve data hazards by directly providing the result of an instruction from an earlier pipeline stage to a later instruction that needs it.
To reorder instructions for out-of-order execution and preserve program order.
To fetch instructions from main memory into the instruction cache.

questions.question: What is the primary objective of Dynamic Voltage and Frequency Scaling (DVFS) in modern processors and SoCs?
options: To improve circuit yield by reducing manufacturing defects.
To dynamically adjust the operating voltage and clock frequency to optimize power consumption and performance.
To completely shut off power to inactive blocks of the chip.
To compensate for clock skew in synchronous digital circuits.
To detect and correct errors in memory during runtime.

questions.question: In a typical computer system, what is the primary function of "main memory" (often implemented with DRAM)?
options: To provide very fast, small storage directly accessible by the CPU registers.
To permanently store the operating system and user applications even when power is off.
To act as the primary, volatile storage location for actively running programs and their data.
To manage the virtual-to-physical address translation process.
To cache frequently accessed data from the hard drive.
